facts.text: Original assessment of the assessee for the assessment year 1944-45 was made sometime before March 13, 1953.
Subsequently after obtaining the sanction of the Commissioner of Income-tax, the Income-tax Officer reopened the assessment under s. 34(1)(a) of the Act.
On March 13, 1953 he issued a notice to the assessee under s. 34 read with s. 22(2) of the Act.
After considering the objection of the assessee, the Income-tax Officer computed the income of the assessee under s. 34 read with s. 23(4) on March 8, 1954 at Rs. 60,000.
The note made by the Income-tax Officer on that day in the order sheet reads: 'Assessed as per assessment order on a total income of Rs. 60,000 for the assessment year 1944-45 under s. 34/23(4)'.
On that date the Income-tax Officer did not determine the tax due from the assessee.
He determined the tax due from the assessee and issued a notice under s. 28(3) in Form 30 only on March 31, 1954.
The assessee contended that the assessment is barred under s. 34(3).
That contention was rejected by the authorities under the Act including the appellate tribunal.
At the instance of the assessee, the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal, A Bench, Calcutta referred to the High Court for its opinion two questions of law.

High Court of Calcutta in Income-tax Reference No. 4 of 1960, judgment dated May 31, 1963, following the decision of the Madras High Court in M. P. R. Viswanathan Chettiar v. Commissioner of Income Tax, Madras accepted the contention of the assessee.

legal_issues.text: Whether the assessment is complete on the date when the income is assessed by the Income-tax Officer or on the date when the tax is computed by him and the challan demanding the tax is issued?
Whether on the facts admitted or found in this case, the assessment was time barred under the first proviso to section 34(3) of the Indian Income-tax Act?

petitioner_arguments.text: The assessment was complete when the income was assessed on March 8, 1954, and thus not time-barred under s.34(3).
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: ss. 23 and 34(3) of the Indian Income Tax Act, 1922

respondent_arguments.text: The assessment is not complete until the tax is computed and challan issued, which happened on March 31, 1954, making it time-barred under the first proviso to s.34(3).
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: s.34(3) of the Indian Income Tax Act, 1922; M. P. R. Viswanathan Chettiar v. Commissioner of Income Tax, Madras

court_reasoning.text: The words 'assessment' and 'assessee' are used in different places in the Act with different meanings; in s.34(3) 'assessment' means not merely computation of income but also determination of tax payable.
court_reasoning.key_observation: High Court of Madras in Viswanathan Chettiar's case concluded that 'assessment' in proviso to s.34(3) includes determination of tax.

court_reasoning.text: No other High Court has taken a contrary view; Revenue acted on that decision for years; interpretation in taxing statute accepted and acted upon should not be easily departed from.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Courts cannot ignore harm by unsettling settled law, especially with 1961 Act having materially different provisions.

court_reasoning.text: Not justified in departing from Madras High Court interpretation though another view possible.

holdings.text: The word 'assessment' in s.34(3) includes determination of tax payable by the assessee.
On facts, assessment was time-barred under first proviso to s.34(3).

precedents_cited.case_name: M. P. R. Viswanathan Chettiar v. Commissioner of Income Tax, Madras
precedents_cited.relevance: Held that 'assessment' in proviso to s.34(3) means not merely computation of income but also determination of tax payable.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Income Tax Act, 1922
statutes_cited.relevance: Governs completion of assessment, reopening, time limits, and reference to High Court.

statutes_cited.name: Income-tax Act, 1961
statutes_cited.relevance: Corresponding provisions materially different from 1922 Act.

outcome.summary: Appeal by Revenue dismissed, upholding High Court's view that assessment under s.34(3) includes tax determination and was time-barred.
outcome.relief_granted: High Court advisory opinion in favour of assessee upheld.

key_quotes.text: "the word assessment in proviso to s. 34(3) means not merely the computation of the income of the assessee but also the determination of the tax payable by him."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Defines key term central to the decision.

key_quotes.text: Interpretation of a provision in a taxing statute rendered years back and accepted and acted upon by the department should not be easily departed from.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Reason for adhering to prior precedent despite possible alternative view.
